required_header.download_date: ClinicalTrials.gov processed this data on July 28, 2020
required_header.link_text: Link to the current ClinicalTrials.gov record.

clinical_study.brief_title: A Pilot Study of GWP42003 in the Symptomatic Treatment of Ulcerative Colitis (GWID10160)
clinical_study.official_title: A Randomised, Double-blind, Placebo-controlled Parallel Group, Pilot Study of GWP42003 in the Symptomatic Treatment of Ulcerative Colitis

brief_summary.textblock: This study was conducted to determine the efficacy and safety of GWP42003 compared with placebo by the percentage of participants achieving remission quantified as a Mayo score of 2 or less (with no sub-score >1) after 10 weeks of treatment.

detailed_description.textblock:
This study was conducted by GW Research Ltd as a pilot study to determine the efficacy and safety of GWP42003 (50 milligram [mg] up to 250 mg twice daily [BID]), compared with placebo, as assessed by the percentage of participants achieving remission quantified as a Mayo score of 2 or less (with no sub-score >1) after 10 weeks of treatment. This was the first study to determine whether the study drug has a positive benefit for participants on their ulcerative colitis symptom control, as well as effects on inflammatory marker cytokines (C reactive protein [CRP]), a fecal inflammatory marker (calprotectin), stool frequency, and rectal bleeding. In addition, various inflammatory bowel disease (IBD) questionnaires were implemented in the study to observe further benefits on the study drug, compared with placebo.
This study was multi-center, randomized, double-blind, placebo-controlled, and parallel-group. The study consisted of a 7-day baseline period, a 10-week treatment period, and a 1-week follow-up period. Each participant had a Mayo assessment (including endoscopy) conducted to confirm eligibility. Eligible participants were randomized in a 1:1 ratio into the GWP42003 and placebo groups. At the start of the treatment period, participants entered a 2-week dose escalation period to achieve their maximum tolerated dose, up to 250 mg BID in the GWP42003 group. Participants remained at the maximum tolerated dose for the rest of the treatment period.

study_design_info.masking: Quadruple (Participant, Care Provider, Investigator, Outcomes Assessor)

primary_outcome.measure: Number Of Participants With A Mayo Score Of 2 Or Less (With No Sub-score >1) At EOT
primary_outcome.time_frame: Baseline to End of Treatment (EOT) (10 weeks) or Early Termination (ET)
primary_outcome.description: The Mayo score is an assessment of ulcerative colitis activity. The Mayo total score ranges from 0 to 12 points with higher scores indicating more severe disease. The total score is made up of 4 sub-scores, each of which is assessed using a 0 to 3 scale. Sub-scores are graded as follows: Stool Frequency: 0 = Normal number of stools, 1 = 1 to 2 stools more than normal, 2 = 3 to 4 stools more than normal, 3 = 5 or more stools more than normal; Rectal Bleeding: 0 = No blood seen, 1 = Streaks of blood with stool less than half the time, 2 = Obvious blood with stool most of the time or more, 3 = Blood alone passes; Findings on Endoscopy: 0 = Normal or inactive disease, 1 = Mild disease (erythema, decreased vascular pattern, mild friability), 2 = Moderate disease (marked erythema, lack of vascular pattern, friability, erosions), 3 = Severe disease (spontaneous bleeding, ulceration); Physician's Global Assessment of Illness Severity (PGAS): 0 = none, 1 = mild, 2 = moderate, and 3 = severe.

primary_outcome.measure: Number Of Participants With A Mayo Score Of 2 Or Less (With No Sub-score >1) At EOT - PP Analysis
primary_outcome.time_frame: Baseline to EOT (10 weeks) or ET
primary_outcome.description: The Mayo score is an assessment of ulcerative colitis activity. The Mayo total score ranges from 0 to 12 points with higher scores indicating more severe disease. The total score is made up of 4 sub-scores, each of which is assessed using a 0 to 3 scale. Sub-scores are graded as follows: Stool Frequency: 0 = Normal number of stools, 1 = 1 to 2 stools more than normal, 2 = 3 to 4 stools more than normal, 3 = 5 or more stools more than normal; Rectal Bleeding: 0 = No blood seen, 1 = Streaks of blood with stool less than half the time, 2 = Obvious blood with stool most of the time or more, 3 = Blood alone passes; Findings on Endoscopy: 0 = Normal or inactive disease, 1 = Mild disease (erythema, decreased vascular pattern, mild friability), 2 = Moderate disease (marked erythema, lack of vascular pattern, friability, erosions), 3 = Severe disease (spontaneous bleeding, ulceration); PGAS: 0 = none, 1 = mild, 2 = moderate, and 3 = severe.

secondary_outcome.measure: Distribution On The PGAS At EOT
secondary_outcome.description: The PGAS required the physician to assess participants' disease severity on a 4-point scale (0=normal [no disease], 1 = mild disease, 2 = moderate disease, 3 = severe disease).

secondary_outcome.measure: Distribution On The PGAS At EOT - PP Analysis
secondary_outcome.description: The PGAS required the physician to assess participants' disease severity on a 4-point scale (0 = normal [no disease], 1 = mild disease, 2 = moderate disease, 3 = severe disease).

secondary_outcome.measure: Change From Baseline To EOT In The PGAS Score
secondary_outcome.time_frame: Baseline to EOT (10 weeks) or ET
secondary_outcome.description: The PGAS required the physician to assess participants' disease severity on a 4-point scale (0=normal [no disease], 1 = mild disease, 2 = moderate disease, 3 = severe disease). A negative change from Baseline indicates that symptoms decreased.

secondary_outcome.measure: Change From Baseline To EOT In The PGAS Score - PP Analysis
secondary_outcome.time_frame: Baseline to EOT (10 weeks) or ET
secondary_outcome.description: The PGAS required the physician to assess participants' disease severity on a 4-point scale (0=normal [no disease], 1 = mild disease, 2 = moderate disease, 3 = severe disease). A negative change from Baseline indicates that symptoms decreased.

secondary_outcome.measure: Change From Baseline To EOT In The Inflammatory Bowel Disease Questionnaire (IBDQ) Total Score
secondary_outcome.time_frame: Baseline to EOT (10 weeks) or ET
secondary_outcome.description: The IBDQ is a validated and reliable tool to measure health-related quality of life in adult participants with inflammatory bowel disease (IBD). Each of the 32 questions falls into 1 of 4 domains (bowel symptoms, systemic symptoms, emotional status and social function). The 32 questions each have 7 possible responses. Each response is assigned a score ranging from 1 to 7, indicating the severity (1 being least favorable and 7 being the most favorable). Individual question scores were summed to give the IBDQ total score (range: 32 to 224 points). A positive change from Baseline indicates that symptoms improved.

secondary_outcome.measure: Change From Baseline To EOT In The IBDQ Total Score - PP Analysis
secondary_outcome.time_frame: Baseline to EOT (10 weeks) or ET
secondary_outcome.description: The IBDQ is a validated and reliable tool to measure health-related quality of life in adult participants with IBD. Each of the 32 questions falls into 1 of 4 domains (bowel symptoms, systemic symptoms, emotional status and social function). The 32 questions each have 7 possible responses. Each response is assigned a score ranging from 1 to 7, indicating the severity (1 being least favorable and 7 being the most favorable). Individual question scores were summed to give the IBDQ total score (range: 32 to 224 points). A positive change from Baseline indicates that symptoms improved.

secondary_outcome.measure: Number Of Participants Who Reported An Improvement In The Subject Global Impression Of Change (SGIC) Questionnaire At EOT
secondary_outcome.time_frame: Visit 4 (Day 43) to EOT (10 weeks) or ET
secondary_outcome.description: Participants were asked to answer the following question by using a 7-point scale (1 = very much better to 7 = very much worse): "Please assess the change in your ulcerative colitis symptoms since immediately before receiving the first dose of study treatment." Improvement was considered as very much better, much better, or minimally better.

secondary_outcome.measure: Number Of Participants Who Reported An Improvement In The SGIC Questionnaire At EOT - PP Analysis
secondary_outcome.time_frame: Visit 4 (Day 43) to EOT (10 weeks) or ET
secondary_outcome.description: Participants were asked to answer the following question by using a 7-point scale (1 = very much better to 7 = very much worse): "Please assess the change in your ulcerative colitis symptoms since immediately before receiving the first dose of study treatment." Improvement was considered as very much better, much better, or minimally better.

secondary_outcome.measure: Change From Baseline To The Last Week Of Treatment In Ulcerative Colitis Symptoms, As Measured By Scores On The Stool Frequency Numerical Rating Scale (NRS)
secondary_outcome.time_frame: Baseline to EOT (last 7 days) or ET
secondary_outcome.description: Participants were required to record their stool frequency during the baseline and treatment periods in a daily diary. Participants graded stool frequency with a 4-point NRS as follows: 0 = Normal number of stools; 1 = 1 to 2 stools more than normal; 2 = 3 to 4 stools more than normal; 3 = 5 or more stools more than normal. For analysis, the baseline value was defined as the mean stool frequency score of the last 7 available days of the baseline period; the EOT value was defined as the mean stool frequency score of last 7 days of the treatment period, or last 7 days for which study drug was taken, where earlier. A negative change from Baseline indicates that symptoms improved.

secondary_outcome.measure: Change From Baseline To The Last Week Of Treatment In Ulcerative Colitis Symptoms, As Measured By Scores On The Stool Frequency NRS - PP Analysis
secondary_outcome.time_frame: Baseline to EOT (last 7 days) or ET
secondary_outcome.description: Participants were required to record their stool frequency during the baseline and treatment periods in a daily diary. Participants graded stool frequency with a 4-point NRS as follows: 0 = Normal number of stools; 1 = 1 to 2 stools more than normal; 2 = 3 to 4 stools more than normal; 3 = 5 or more stools more than normal. For analysis, the baseline value was defined as the mean stool frequency score of the last 7 available days of the baseline period; the EOT value was defined as the mean stool frequency score of last 7 days of the treatment period, or last 7 days for which study drug was taken, where earlier. A negative change from Baseline indicates that symptoms improved.

secondary_outcome.measure: Change From Baseline To The Last Week Of Treatment In Ulcerative Colitis Symptoms, As Measured By Scores On The Rectal Bleeding NRS
secondary_outcome.time_frame: Baseline to EOT (last 7 days) or ET
secondary_outcome.description: Participants were required to record their rectal bleeding during the baseline and treatment periods in a daily diary. Participants graded rectal bleeding with a 4-point NRS as follows: 0 = No blood seen, 1 = Streaks of blood with stool less than half the time, 2 = Obvious blood with stool most of the time or more, 3 = Blood alone passes. For analysis, the baseline value was defined as the mean rectal bleeding score of the last 7 available days of the baseline period; the EOT value was defined as the mean rectal bleeding score of last 7 days of the treatment period, or last 7 days for which study drug was taken, where earlier. A negative change from Baseline indicates that symptoms improved.

secondary_outcome.measure: Change From Baseline To The Last Week Of Treatment In Ulcerative Colitis Symptoms, As Measured By Scores On The Rectal Bleeding NRS - PP Analysis
secondary_outcome.time_frame: Baseline to EOT (last 7 days) or ET
secondary_outcome.description: Participants were required to record their rectal bleeding during the baseline and treatment periods in a daily diary. Participants graded rectal bleeding with a 4-point NRS as follows: 0 = No blood seen, 1 = Streaks of blood with stool less than half the time, 2 = Obvious blood with stool most of the time or more, 3 = Blood alone passes. For analysis, the baseline value was defined as the mean rectal bleeding score of the last 7 available days of the baseline period; the EOT value was defined as the mean rectal bleeding score of last 7 days of the treatment period, or last 7 days for which study drug was taken, where earlier. A negative change from Baseline indicates that symptoms improved.

secondary_outcome.measure: Change From Baseline To EOT In The Mayo Total Score
secondary_outcome.time_frame: Baseline to EOT (10 weeks) or ET
secondary_outcome.description: The Mayo score is an assessment of ulcerative colitis activity. The Mayo total score ranges from 0 to 12 points with higher scores indicating more severe disease. The total score is made up of 4 sub-scores (assessed using a 0 to 3 scale). The sub-scores are graded as follows: Stool Frequency: 0 = Normal number of stools, 1 = 1 to 2 stools more than normal, 2 = 3 to 4 stools more than normal, 3 = 5 or more stools more than normal; Rectal Bleeding: 0 = No blood seen, 1 = Streaks of blood with stool less than half the time, 2 = Obvious blood with stool most of the time or more, 3 = Blood alone passes; Findings on Endoscopy: 0 = Normal or inactive disease, 1 = Mild disease (erythema, decreased vascular pattern, mild friability), 2 = Moderate disease (marked erythema, lack of vascular pattern, friability, erosions), 3 = Severe disease (spontaneous bleeding, ulceration); PGAS: 0 = none, 1 = mild, 2 = moderate and 3 = severe. A negative change from Baseline indicates that symptoms improved.

secondary_outcome.measure: Change From Baseline To EOT In The Mayo Partial Score
secondary_outcome.time_frame: Baseline to EOT (10 weeks) or ET
secondary_outcome.description: The Mayo score is an assessment of ulcerative colitis activity. The Mayo partial score does not include the endoscopy findings sub-score and ranges from 0 to 9 points with higher scores indicating more severe disease. The partial score is made up of 3 sub-scores (assessed by using a 0 to 3 scale). The sub-scores are graded as follows: Stool Frequency: 0 = Normal number of stools, 1 = 1 to 2 stools more than normal, 2 = 3 to 4 stools more than normal, 3 = 5 or more stools more than normal; Rectal Bleeding: 0 = No blood seen, 1 = Streaks of blood with stool less than half the time, 2 = Obvious blood with stool most of the time or more, 3 = Blood alone passes; PGAS: 0 = none, 1 = mild, 2 = moderate and 3 = severe. A negative change from Baseline indicates that symptoms improved.

secondary_outcome.measure: Change From Baseline To EOT In Levels Of Fecal Calprotectin
secondary_outcome.time_frame: Baseline to EOT (10 weeks) or ET
secondary_outcome.description: Fecal calprotectin is a marker of inflammation. Standard methods were used to measure the levels of calprotectin in fecal samples collected at the end of baseline and treatment periods. A negative change from Baseline indicates that levels of fecal calprotectin decreased.

arm_group.description: GWP42003 was administered orally at a dose of 50 mg up to 250 mg, BID, in the fasted state in the morning and evening, for 10 weeks. Following randomization, participants entered a 2-week dose escalation period to achieve their maximum tolerated dose, up to 500 mg, and maintained this dose for the rest of the treatment period. Participants were then followed for 1 week.
Placebo capsules matching the study drug were administered orally, BID, in the fasted state in the morning and evening, for 10 weeks. Participants were then followed for 1 week.

results_reference.citation: Irving PM, Iqbal T, Nwokolo C, Subramanian S, Bloom S, Prasad N, Hart A, Murray C, Lindsay JO, Taylor A, Barron R, Wright S. A Randomized, Double-blind, Placebo-controlled, Parallel-group, Pilot Study of Cannabidiol-rich Botanical Extract in the Symptomatic Treatment of Ulcerative Colitis. Inflamm Bowel Dis. 2018 Mar 19;24(4):714-724. doi: 10.1093/ibd/izy002.

group.title: GWP42003
group.description: GWP42003 was administered orally at a dose of 50 milligram (mg) up to 250 mg, twice daily (BID), in the fasted state in the morning and evening, for 10 weeks. Following randomization, participants entered a 2-week dose escalation period to achieve their maximum tolerated dose, up to 500 mg, and maintained this dose for the rest of the treatment period. Participants were then followed for 1 week.

group.title: Placebo
group.description: Placebo capsules matching the study drug were administered orally, BID, in the fasted state in the morning and evening, for 10 weeks. Participants were then followed for 1 week.

measure.population: ITT analysis set: all participants who were randomized and received at least 1 dose of study drug. Participants were analyzed according to the group to which they were randomized. Not all participants contributed data for the outcome measure.

outcome.title: Change From Baseline To EOT In The IBDQ Total Score - PP Analysis
outcome.description: The IBDQ is a validated and reliable tool to measure health-related quality of life in adult participants with IBD. Each of the 32 questions falls into 1 of 4 domains (bowel symptoms, systemic symptoms, emotional status and social function). The 32 questions each have 7 possible responses. Each response is assigned a score ranging from 1 to 7, indicating the severity (1 being least favorable and 7 being the most favorable). Individual question scores were summed to give the IBDQ total score (range: 32 to 224 points). A positive change from Baseline indicates that symptoms improved.
outcome.time_frame: Baseline to EOT (10 weeks) or ET
outcome.population: PP analysis set: all participants who completed the 10-week randomized phase of the study with no protocol violations deemed to compromise the assessments of efficacy. Not all participants contributed data for this outcome measure.

group.title: GWP42003
group.description: GWP42003 was administered orally at a dose of 50 mg up to 250 mg, BID, in the fasted state in the morning and evening, for 10 weeks. Following randomization, participants entered a 2-week dose escalation period to achieve their maximum tolerated dose, up to 500 mg, and maintained this dose for the rest of the treatment period. Participants were then followed for 1 week.

group.title: Placebo
group.description: Placebo capsules matching the study drug were administered orally, BID, in the fasted state in the morning and evening, for 10 weeks. Participants were then followed for 1 week.

measure.title: Change From Baseline To EOT In The IBDQ Total Score - PP Analysis
measure.description: The IBDQ is a validated and reliable tool to measure health-related quality of life in adult participants with IBD. Each of the 32 questions falls into 1 of 4 domains (bowel symptoms, systemic symptoms, emotional status and social function). The 32 questions each have 7 possible responses. Each response is assigned a score ranging from 1 to 7, indicating the severity (1 being least favorable and 7 being the most favorable). Individual question scores were summed to give the IBDQ total score (range: 32 to 224 points). A positive change from Baseline indicates that symptoms improved.
measure.population: PP analysis set: all participants who completed the 10-week randomized phase of the study with no protocol violations deemed to compromise the assessments of efficacy. Not all participants contributed data for this outcome measure.

outcome.title: Number Of Participants Who Reported An Improvement In The Subject Global Impression Of Change (SGIC) Questionnaire At EOT
outcome.description: Participants were asked to answer the following question by using a 7-point scale (1 = very much better to 7 = very much worse): "Please assess the change in your ulcerative colitis symptoms since immediately before receiving the first dose of study treatment." Improvement was considered as very much better, much better, or minimally better.
outcome.time_frame: Visit 4 (Day 43) to EOT (10 weeks) or ET
outcome.population: ITT analysis set: all participants who were randomized and received at least 1 dose of study drug. Participants were analyzed according to the group to which they were randomized. Not all participants contributed data for this outcome measure.

Participants were then followed for 1 week.

outcome.description: Participants were asked to answer the following question by using a 7-point scale (1 = very much better to 7 = very much worse): "Please assess the change in your ulcerative colitis symptoms since immediately before receiving the first dose of study treatment." group.description: GWP42003 was administered orally at a dose of 50 mg up to 250 mg, BID, in the fasted state in the morning and evening, for 10 weeks. group.description: Placebo capsules matching the study drug were administered orally, BID, in the fasted state in the morning and evening, for 10 weeks. Participants were then followed for 1 week.

measure.title: Number Of Participants Who Reported An Improvement In The SGIC Questionnaire At EOT - PP Analysis
measure.description: Participants were asked to answer the following question by using a 7-point scale (1 = very much better to 7 = very much worse): "Please assess the change in your ulcerative colitis symptoms since immediately before receiving the first dose of study treatment." Improvement was considered as very much better, much better, or minimally better.
measure.population: PP analysis set: all participants who completed the 10-week randomized phase of the study with no protocol violations deemed to compromise the assessments of efficacy. Not all participants contributed data for this outcome measure.

outcome.title: Change From Baseline To The Last Week Of Treatment In Ulcerative Colitis Symptoms, As Measured By Scores On The Stool Frequency Numerical Rating Scale (NRS)
outcome.description: Participants were required to record their stool frequency during the baseline and treatment periods in a daily diary. Participants graded stool frequency with a 4-point NRS as follows: 0 = Normal number of stools; 1 = 1 to 2 stools more than normal; 2 = 3 to 4 stools more than normal; 3 = 5 or more stools more than normal. For analysis, the baseline value was defined as the mean stool frequency score of the last 7 available days of the baseline period; the EOT value was defined as the mean stool frequency score of last 7 days of the treatment period, or last 7 days for which study drug was taken, where earlier. A negative change from Baseline indicates that symptoms improved.
outcome.time_frame: Baseline to EOT (last 7 days) or ET
outcome.population: ITT analysis set: all participants who were randomized and received at least 1 dose of study drug. Participants were analyzed according to the group to which they were randomized. Not all participants contributed data for this outcome measure.

Participants were then followed for 1 week.

measure.title: Change From Baseline To The Last Week Of Treatment In Ulcerative Colitis Symptoms, As Measured By Scores On The Stool Frequency NRS - PP Analysis
measure.description: Participants were required to record their stool frequency during the baseline and treatment periods in a daily diary. outcome.title: Change From Baseline To The Last Week Of Treatment In Ulcerative Colitis Symptoms, As Measured By Scores On The Rectal Bleeding NRS
outcome.description: Participants were required to record their rectal bleeding during the baseline and treatment periods in a daily diary. Participants graded rectal bleeding with a 4-point NRS as follows: 0 = No blood seen, 1 = Streaks of blood with stool less than half the time, 2 = Obvious blood with stool most of the time or more, 3 = Blood alone passes. For analysis, the baseline value was defined as the mean rectal bleeding score of the last 7 available days of the baseline period; the EOT value was defined as the mean rectal bleeding score of last 7 days of the treatment period, or last 7 days for which study drug was taken, where earlier. A negative change from Baseline indicates that symptoms improved.
outcome.time_frame: Baseline to EOT (last 7 days) or ET
outcome.population: ITT analysis set: all participants who were randomized and received at least 1 dose of study drug. Participants were analyzed according to the group to which they were randomized. Not all participants contributed data for this outcome measure.

measure.title: Change From Baseline To The Last Week Of Treatment In Ulcerative Colitis Symptoms, As Measured By Scores On The Rectal Bleeding NRS - PP Analysis
measure.description: Participants were required to record their rectal bleeding during the baseline and treatment periods in a daily diary. Participants graded rectal bleeding with a 4-point NRS as follows: 0 = No blood seen, 1 = Streaks of blood with stool less than half the time, 2 = Obvious blood with stool most of the time or more, 3 = Blood alone passes. For analysis, the baseline value was defined as the mean rectal bleeding score of the last 7 available days of the baseline period; the EOT value was defined as the mean rectal bleeding score of last 7 days of the treatment period, or last 7 days for which study drug was taken, where earlier. A negative change from Baseline indicates that symptoms improved.
measure.population: PP analysis set: all participants who completed the 10-week randomized phase of the study with no protocol violations deemed to compromise the assessments of efficacy.

outcome.title: Change From Baseline To EOT In The Mayo Total Score
outcome.description: The Mayo score is an assessment of ulcerative colitis activity. The Mayo total score ranges from 0 to 12 points with higher scores indicating more severe disease. The total score is made up of 4 sub-scores (assessed using a 0 to 3 scale). The sub-scores are graded as follows: Stool Frequency: 0 = Normal number of stools, 1 = 1 to 2 stools more than normal, 2 = 3 to 4 stools more than normal, 3 = 5 or more stools more than normal; Rectal Bleeding: 0 = No blood seen, 1 = Streaks of blood with stool less than half the time, 2 = Obvious blood with stool most of the time or more, 3 = Blood alone passes; Findings on Endoscopy: 0 = Normal or inactive disease, 1 = Mild disease (erythema, decreased vascular pattern, mild friability), 2 = Moderate disease (marked erythema, lack of vascular pattern, friability, erosions), 3 = Severe disease (spontaneous bleeding, ulceration); PGAS: 0 = none, 1 = mild, 2 = moderate and 3 = severe. A negative change from Baseline indicates that symptoms improved.
outcome.time_frame: Baseline to EOT (10 weeks) or ET
outcome.population: ITT analysis set: all participants who were randomized and received at least 1 dose of study drug. Participants were analyzed according to the group to which they were randomized. Not all participants contributed data for this outcome measure.

group.title: GWP42003
group.description: GWP42003 was administered orally at a dose of 50 mg up to 250 mg, BID, in the fasted state in the morning and evening, for 10 weeks. Following randomization, participants entered a 2-week dose escalation period to achieve their maximum tolerated dose, up to 500 mg, and maintained this dose for the rest of the treatment period. Participants were then followed for 1 week.

group.title: Placebo
group.description: Placebo capsules matching the study drug were administered orally, BID, in the fasted state in the morning and evening, for 10 weeks. Participants were then followed for 1 week.

measure.title: Change From Baseline To EOT In The Mayo Total Score
measure.description: The Mayo score is an assessment of ulcerative colitis activity. The Mayo total score ranges from 0 to 12 points with higher scores indicating more severe disease. The total score is made up of 4 sub-scores (assessed using a 0 to 3 scale). The sub-scores are graded as follows: Stool Frequency: 0 = Normal number of stools, 1 = 1 to 2 stools more than normal, 2 = 3 to 4 stools more than normal, 3 = 5 or more stools more than normal; Rectal Bleeding: 0 = No blood seen, 1 = Streaks of blood with stool less than half the time, 2 = Obvious blood with stool most of the time or more, 3 = Blood alone passes; Findings on Endoscopy: 0 = Normal or inactive disease, 1 = Mild disease (erythema, decreased vascular pattern, mild friability), 2 = Moderate disease (marked erythema, lack of vascular pattern, friability, erosions), 3 = Severe disease (spontaneous bleeding, ulceration); PGAS: 0 = none, 1 = mild, 2 = moderate and 3 = severe. A negative change from Baseline indicates that symptoms improved.
measure.population: ITT analysis set: all participants who were randomized and received at least 1 dose of study drug. Participants were analyzed according to the group to which they were randomized. Not all participants contributed data for this outcome measure.

outcome.title: Change From Baseline To EOT In The Mayo Partial Score
outcome.description: The Mayo score is an assessment of ulcerative colitis activity. The Mayo partial score does not include the endoscopy findings sub-score and ranges from 0 to 9 points with higher scores indicating more severe disease. The partial score is made up of 3 sub-scores (assessed by using a 0 to 3 scale). The sub-scores are graded as follows: Stool Frequency: 0 = Normal number of stools, 1 = 1 to 2 stools more than normal, 2 = 3 to 4 stools more than normal, 3 = 5 or more stools more than normal; Rectal Bleeding: 0 = No blood seen, 1 = Streaks of blood with stool less than half the time, 2 = Obvious blood with stool most of the time or more, 3 = Blood alone passes; PGAS: 0 = none, 1 = mild, 2 = moderate and 3 = severe. A negative change from Baseline indicates that symptoms improved.

outcome.title: Change From Baseline To EOT In Levels Of Fecal Calprotectin
outcome.description: Fecal calprotectin is a marker of inflammation. Standard methods were used to measure the levels of calprotectin in fecal samples collected at the end of baseline and treatment periods. A negative change from Baseline indicates that levels of fecal calprotectin decreased.
outcome.time_frame: Baseline to EOT (10 weeks) or ET
outcome.population: ITT analysis set: all participants who were randomized and received at least 1 dose of study drug. Participants were analyzed according to the group to which they were randomized. Not all participants contributed data for this outcome measure.

reported_events.time_frame: Post-dose on Day 1 through 14 days after the final dose (up to 85 days).
reported_events.desc: Safety analysis set: All randomized participants who received at least one dose of study drug and were analyzed according to the treatment received.

group.title: GWP42003
group.description: GWP42003 was administered orally at a dose of 50 mg up to 250 mg, BID, in the fasted state in the morning and evening, for 10 weeks. Following randomization, participants entered a 2-week dose escalation period to achieve their maximum tolerated dose, up to 500 mg, and maintained this dose for the rest of the treatment period. Participants were then followed for 1 week.

group.title: Placebo
group.description: Placebo capsules matching the study drug were administered orally, BID, in the fasted state in the morning and evening, for 10 weeks. Participants were then followed for 1 week.

certain_agreements.pi_employee: Principal Investigators are NOT employed by the organization sponsoring the study.
certain_agreements.restrictive_agreement: The only disclosure restriction on the PI is that the sponsor can review results communications prior to public release and can embargo communications regarding trial results for a period that is more than 60 days but less than or equal to 180 days from the time submitted to the sponsor for review. The sponsor cannot require changes to the communication and cannot extend the embargo.
